Definitions.Definition_Content: An integral domain $R$ is called a Euclidean domain if it admits a map $\delta: R-\{0\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ making possible Euclidean division in $R$ in the following sense: Given elements $f, g \in R, g \neq 0$, there are elements $q, r \in R$ such that $f=q g+r$, where $\delta(r)<\delta(g)$ or $r=0$.
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.

Let $R$ be an integral domain and $p \in R$ a nonzero nonunit. $p$ is called irreducible if a factorization of type $p=x y$ with $x, y \in R$ implies $x \in R^{*}$ or $y \in R^{*}$. Furthermore, $p$ is called reducible if it is not irreducible.

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: Every Euclidean domain is a principal ideal domain.
The rings $\mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{Z}[i]$, as well as the polynomial ring $K[X]$ over a field $K$, are Euclidean domains and hence principal ideal domains.
Let $R$ be a principal ideal domain and $p \in R$ a nonzero nonunit. The following conditions are equivalent: (i) $p$ is irreducible. (ii) $p$ is a prime element. (iii) (p) is a maximal ideal in $R$.
Let $R$ be a principal ideal domain. Then every nonzero nonunit $a \in R$ is a product of prime elements.

Every principal ideal domain $R$ is Noetherian, i.e., every ascending chain of ideals $\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R$ becomes stationary in the sense that there is some $n \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $\mathfrak{a}_{i}=\mathfrak{a}_{n}$ for all $i \geq n$.

Let $R$ be an integral domain. For an element $a \in R$, consider factorizations $a=p_{1} \ldots p_{r}=q_{1} \ldots q_{s}$ into prime elements $p_{i}$ and irreducible elements $q_{j}$. Then $r=s$, and one can renumber the $q_{j}$ in such a way that $p_{i}$ is associated to $q_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, r$.

Let $R$ be a unique factorization domain and let $P$ be a system of representatives of all prime elements in $R$. If $x_{i}=\varepsilon_{i} \prod_{p \in P} p^{
u_{p}\left(x_{i}ight)}, \quad i=1, \ldots, n$ are prime factorizations of elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$, then $\operatorname{gcd}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}ight)$ and $\operatorname{lcm}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}ight)$ exist and are given by $\operatorname{gcd}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}ight)=\prod_{p \in P} p^{\min \left(
u_{p}\left(x_{1}ight), \ldots, 
u_{p}\left(x_{n}ight)ight)}$ and $\operatorname{lcm}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}ight)=\prod_{p \in P} p^{\max \left(
u_{p}\left(x_{1}ight), \ldots, 
u_{p}\left(x_{n}ight)ight)}$ up to associatedness.

Let $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be elements of an integral domain $R$. (i) If $\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$, the ideal generated by the $x_{i}$ in $R$, is principal, say generated by an element $d \in R$, then $d=\operatorname{gcd}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$. (ii) If $\left(x_{1}\right) \cap \ldots \cap\left(x_{n}\right)$ is a principal ideal, say generated by an element $v \in R$, then $v=\operatorname{lcm}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$.

Let $R$ be a Euclidean domain. For two elements $x, y \in R-\{0\}$ consider the sequence $z_{0}, z_{1}, \ldots \in R$, which is inductively given by $z_{0} =x, z_{1} =y, z_{i+1} =\left\{\begin{array}{l} \text { the remainder of } z_{i-1} \text { with respect to division by } z_{i} \text { if } z_{i} \neq 0, \ 0 \text { otherwise. } \end{array}\right.$. Then $z_{i}=0$ for almost all $i \in \mathbb{N}$. Furthermore, $z_{n}=\operatorname{gcd}(x, y)$, where $n \in \mathbb{N} is the smallest index satisfying $z_{n+1}=0$.
